{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
The '''Good Friday closure controversy''' or '''Good Friday Disagreement'''<ref>{{cite web|author=Billy Keane|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/rugby/billy-keane-ales-well-that-ends-well-for-rugby-fans-2114253.html|title=Ale's well that ends well for rugby fans|date=27 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''|quote=The papers are full of the Good Friday Disagreement.}}</ref> refers to the 2010 court case which saw publicans in [[Limerick]], Ireland apply to be exempted from the prohibition on selling alcohol on [[Good Friday]] of that year.
The case came about following the scheduling of a [[2009–10 Celtic League]] match between [[Munster Rugby|Munster]] and [[Leinster Rugby|Leinster]] at [[Thomond Park]] in the city on 2 April 2010 which coincided with Good Friday that year. Pubs in Ireland are normally not permitted to open on either Good Friday or Christmas Day.<ref name="Licensed vintners to seek permission for Good Friday trading"/> This law, dating from 1927, also originally included [[Saint Patrick's Day]], though that prohibition was later repealed.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jerome Reilly|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/pub-owners-raise-bar-in-bid-to-end-good-friday-drinking-ban-2091445.html|title=Pub owners raise bar in bid to end Good Friday drinking ban|date=7 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]''}}</ref> Drinkers often dodge the law by taking to trains, upon which alcohol is allowed, and having their parties there.<ref>{{cite web|author=Michael Kelly |url=http://www.catholicreview.org/subpages/storyworldnew-new.aspx?action=7901 |title=Court rules pubs in Irish city can open Good Friday for rugby match |date=28 March 2010 |accessdate=28 March 2010 |publisher=''[[The Catholic Review]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725150908/http://www.catholicreview.org/subpages/storyworldnew-new.aspx?action=7901 |archivedate=25 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> In 1910, pubs in [[Athlone]] faced a similar dilemma about opening on Saint Patrick's Day but remained closed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westmeathindependent.ie/news/pagesfromthepast/articles/2010/03/10/3995535-pages-from-the-past/|title=1910: Should Athlone pubs close on St Patrick's Day?|date=10 March 2010|accessdate=28 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Westmeath Independent]]''}}</ref>
The match had sold out by the time the court application took place.<ref name="Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0309/limerick.html|title=Limerick vintners meet senior gardaí|date=9 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Dwane|url=http://www.limerickleader.ie/news/Limerick-publicans-go-to-court.6164212.jp|title=Limerick publicans go to court after failing to obtain Good Friday agreement|date=20 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Limerick Leader]]''}}</ref> It was due to kick off at 20:05 and television rights had already been agreed.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jimmy Woulfe|url=http://www.examiner.ie/ireland/publicans-seek-good-friday-rugby-exemption-in-court-114624.html|title=Publicans seek Good Friday rugby exemption in court|date=16 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Irish Examiner]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Gerry Thornley|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0306/1224265712983.html|title=Fizz is taken out of Good Friday match|date=6 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}}</ref> Vintners argued that Limerick publicans stood to lose revenue valued at around €6 million or as much as €10 million if they were prevented from opening for business as normal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/limerick-vinters-to-launch-court-bid-to-open-on-good-friday-450074.html|title=Limerick vinters to launch court bid to open on Good Friday|date=15 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=breakingnews.ie}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= Mike Dwane|url=http://www.limerickleader.ie/news/Gardai-and-Limerick-publicans-meet.6133350.jp|title=Gardai and Limerick publicans meet over Good Friday opening for rugby fans|date=8 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Limerick Leader]]''}}</ref> The State and the [[Garda Síochána]] opposed a change.<ref name="Good Friday ban for pubs faces legal test"/><ref name="Limerick pubs to open on Good Friday"/> It was considered a landmark case even before it had begun,<ref name="Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling"/><ref name="Good Friday ban for pubs faces legal test"/> and at the end was hailed as an "historic ruling",<ref name="Publicans toast court ruling on historic Good Friday opening"/> and a watershed in Church-State relations.<ref name="Irish pubs to open on Good Friday as locals worship rugby">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ireland/7527013/Irish-pubs-to-open-on-Good-Friday-as-locals-worship-rugby.html|title=Irish pubs to open on Good Friday as locals worship rugby|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''}}</ref>
The vintners won and pubs were permitted to do business on Good Friday in the Republic of Ireland for the first time since 1927 (though only in Limerick).<ref name="Good Friday beer for fans while the Church fears for their spirits"/><ref name="Publicans toast court ruling on historic Good Friday opening"/><ref name="Irish pubs to open on Good Friday as locals worship rugby"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Shawn Pogatchnik |url=http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/world/ci_14756401 |title=Irish pubs to open on Good Friday for first time |date=25 March 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2010 |publisher=''[[Santa Cruz Sentinel]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120909151611/http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/world/ci_14756401 |archivedate=9 September 2012 |df= }}</ref> Commentators such as [[Ian O'Doherty]] in the ''[[Irish Independent]]'' expressed disappointment that it would still be illegal to sell alcohol in [[Dublin]] on the same day.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Ian O'Doherty]]|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/columnists/ian-odoherty/ian-odoherty-this-good-friday-ban-is-driving-me-to-drink-2112469.html|title=Ian O'Doherty: This Good Friday ban is driving me to drink|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:HeinekenCupFinal06MunsterVBiarritz200506SmallByMike.JPG|right|thumb|[[Munster Rugby|Munster]] fans inside [[Millennium Stadium]]]] Attempts to have the date of the match changed to the day before or the day after Good Friday were unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0308/limerick.html|title=Limerick vintners hope to open on Good Friday|date=8 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref> On 9 March 2010, and with no alternative date offered for the match, vintners' representatives, [[Willie O'Dea affidavit incident|recently resigned]] [[Minister for Defence (Ireland)|Minister for Defence]] [[Willie O'Dea]], and Mayor of Limerick [[Kevin Kiely]] were among those to discuss the issue with the Garda Síochána in Limerick.<ref name="Good Friday ban for pubs faces legal test">{{cite web|author=Barry Duggan|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/good-friday-ban-for-pubs-faces-legal-test-2093474.html|title=Good Friday ban for pubs faces legal test|date=10 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> A legal application was determined to be the best solution with "no other option" available.<ref name="Good Friday ban for pubs faces legal test"/>
The controversy divided religious groups in Ireland, many of which were concerned with the preservation of the holiness of Good Friday.<ref name="Licensed vintners to seek permission for Good Friday trading"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Áine de Paor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0309/1224265879028.html|title=Priest calls for debate on Good Friday game|date=9 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Luke Holmes|url=http://www.limerickleader.ie/news/Moyross-monks-consider-prayerful-protest.6147374.jp|title=Moyross monks consider prayerful protest if Munster match goes ahead on Good Friday|date=12 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Limerick Leader]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Dwayne|url=http://www.limerickleader.ie/news/Switch-Good-Friday-match-to.6136739.jp|title=Switch Good Friday match to solve spiritual crux|date=10 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Limerick Leader]]''}}</ref> {{cquote|I heard someone quoted this week who said that rugby is more important than religion – that's just ridiculous and it's a shame. If you identify yourself as a Catholic then you should be nowhere near Thomond Park or a pub on that day. [...] This is like something out of the [[Old Testament]]. If you're going against God and making a public stand about it then you are serving [[Mammon]] over God. I don't care how much money you pull in, it will backfire on you on a spiritual level.—<small>Brother Sean O'Connor, head of the Franciscan Friars in [[Moyross]] who landed from the United States in 2007, gives his opinion on the controversy.</small><ref name="Good Friday beer for fans while the Church fears for their spirits">{{cite web|author=David Sharrock|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/ireland/article7076549.ece|title=Good Friday beer for fans while the Church fears for their spirits|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Times]]''}}</ref><ref name="Good Friday ban for pubs faces legal test"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Áine de Paor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0310/1224265978726.html|title=Limerick friar condemns Good Friday rugby match|date=10 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}}</ref>}}
==Seanad Éireann debate== The issue was debated in [[Seanad Éireann]]. [[Joe O'Toole]] requested a change in the law, saying: “Everyone’s a winner. Free will prevails, the Church-State separation is maintained. We render to Munster the things that are Munster's and to God the things that are God's. We save jobs. The economy gains”.<ref name="Good Friday match discussed"/> [[Ivana Bacik]] echoed those sentiments when she said: “Let those of us who don't believe that Good Friday is a particularly special day choose to do what we want to do in pubs and clubs”.<ref name="Good Friday match discussed"/> [[David Norris (politician)|David Norris]] described as "outrageous" the decision to play a rugby match on Good Friday, bemoaning that Sundays had already fallen to "the British multinationals".<ref name="Good Friday match discussed"/> [[Eoghan Harris]] described the notion of a Good Friday rugby match as "odd and wrong" in a land "impregnated with Christian symbolism".<ref name="Good Friday match discussed"/> [[Donie Cassidy]] lamented the lack of respect for "the crucifixion of the Good Lord".<ref name="Good Friday match discussed">{{cite web|author=Jimmy Walsh|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0310/1224265978595.html|title=Good Friday match discussed|date=10 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}}</ref> [[Minister for Justice and Equality|Minister for Justice and Law Reform]] [[Dermot Ahern]], when asked for his opinion, said the issue was for the courts.<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Cullen|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0311/1224266046114.html|title=Self-regulation of alcohol sales is working, says Ahern|date=11 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''|quote=Asked about calls by Limerick publicans to be allowed to open on Good Friday, April 2nd, to facilitate fans attending a Munster-Leinster rugby match in Thomond Park that day, Mr Ahern said the courts would have to decide the matter. In relation to liberalising pub opening hours to allow opening generally on Good Friday or Christmas Day, he said it was better to "hasten slowly".}}</ref>
==Court application== On 15 March 2010, 60 vintners voted to apply for the exemption at the courthouse in Limerick on 23 March 2010.<ref name="Licensed vintners to seek permission for Good Friday trading">{{cite web|author=David Raleigh |url=http://www.limerickindependent.com/local-news/local-news/licensed-vintners-to-seek-permission-for-good-friday-trading/ |title=Licensed vintners to seek permission for Good Friday trading |date=16 March 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2010 |publisher=''[[Limerick Independent]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713210633/http://www.limerickindependent.com/local-news/local-news/licensed-vintners-to-seek-permission-for-good-friday-trading/ |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0315/limerick.html|title=Limerick vintners seek Good Friday exemption|date=15 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Andrew Carey|url=http://www.limerickpost.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1593:publicans-lodge-application-to-open-on-good-friday&catid=37:local-news&Itemid=60|title=Publicans lodge application to open on Good Friday|date=15 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Limerick Post]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thepost.ie/breakingnews/ireland/eyojauauqley/ |title=Limerick vinters to launch court bid to open on Good Friday |date=15 March 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2010 |publisher=''[[The Sunday Business Post]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726213621/http://www.thepost.ie/breakingnews/ireland/eyojauauqley/ |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> This was thought to be the first time that the Good Friday alcohol ban had been challenged by publicans.<ref>{{cite web|author=Barry Duggan|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/60-publicans-sign-up-for-landmark-good-friday-challenge-2100126.html|title=60 publicans sign up for landmark Good Friday challenge|date=16 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> Sweeney McGann Solicitors of Limerick acted for the Vinters. Chairman of Limerick's Vintners Federation Jerry O'Dea applied to Limerick District Court for an exemption under Section 10 of the Intoxicating liquor Act 1962.<ref name="Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling"/><ref name="Limerick pubs to open for game on Good Friday"/> Mayor of Limerick Kevin Kiely wrote a letter in support of the application.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0304/limerick.html |title=Limerick Mayor backs licensing laws changes |date=4 March 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2010 |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308050744/http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0304/limerick.html |archivedate=8 March 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.limerickpost.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1570:mayor-supports-pubs-good-friday-opening&catid=37:local-news&Itemid=60|title=Mayor supports pubs Good Friday opening|date=6 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Limerick Post]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0306/limerick.html|title=Limerick Mayor supports license law changes|date=6 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref> Gearoid McGann was the solicitor representing the vintners and Michael Murray represented the Garda Síochána and the State.<ref name="Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling">{{cite web|author=Andrew Carey|url=http://www.limerickpost.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1619:cheers-from-publicans-to-landmark-ruling&catid=37:local-news&Itemid=60|title=Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Limerick Post]]''}}</ref><ref name="Publicans toast court ruling on historic Good Friday opening"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Áine de Paor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0323/breaking84.html|title=Gardaí object to Good Friday opening|date=23 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}}</ref> The [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Limerick]] did not object in court.<ref>{{cite web|author=Barry Duggan|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/church-will-not-object-to--pubs-opening-for-big-game-2099252.html|title=Church will not object to pubs opening for big game|date=15 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref>
Judge Tom O'Donnell delayed the verdict until 9:30 on 25 March 2010, citing that he would have to examine case law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0323/limerick.html|title=Decision on Good Friday pub closures delayed|date=23 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.limerickleader.ie/news/Anxious-wait-for-Limerick-publicans.6173924.jp|title=Anxious wait for Limerick publicans following Good Friday court application|date=23 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Limerick Leader]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Jimmy Woulfe|url=http://www.examiner.ie/ireland/good-friday-pub-opening-ruling-to-be-given-tomorrow-115373.html|title=Good Friday pub opening ruling to be given tomorrow|date=24 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Irish Examiner]]''}}</ref> At more than 90 minutes, the hearing proved to be longer than the actual rugby match.<ref>{{cite web|author=Barry Duggan|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/publicans-sweating-on-good-friday-decision-2108851.html|title=Publicans sweating on Good Friday decision|date=24 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref>
President of the Vintners Federation of Ireland (VFI) Dave Hickey had been quoted in the ''[[Irish Independent]]'' on 2 March 2010 as saying there was "not a hope in the world" that any judge would exempt Limerick's pubs.<ref>{{cite web|author=''[[Irish Independent]]'' |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/business/business-news/pub-owners-fury-over-good-friday--munster---leinster--rugby-clash-14704245.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120721222505/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/business/business-news/pub-owners-fury-over-good-friday--munster---leinster--rugby-clash-14704245.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 July 2012 |title=Pub owners fury over Good Friday Munster Leinster rugby clash |date=2 March 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2010 |publisher=''[[The Belfast Telegraph]]'' }}</ref> Munster captain [[Paul O'Connell]] was quoted by ''[[The Irish Times]]'' as being in favour of the exemption for economic reasons.<ref>{{cite web|author=John O'Sullivan|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0317/1224266436672.html|title=O'Connell taking nothing for granted|date=17 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''|quote=On a lighter note the Munster captain accepted that any primacy in Limerick sporting life has been usurped by the decision to make Keith Earls the Grand Marshal for today's St Patrick's Day parade. O'Connell laughed when suggesting it was a Thomond RFC conspiracy. He also found time to offer his perspective on the Good Friday agreement: the one with the small “a” that concerns the upcoming Celtic League game between Munster and Leinster that will be played on a day when pubs in Limerick won’t ordinarily be open. The Ireland secondrow favours an exception being made, citing the financial windfall it would generate in tough economic times.}}</ref>
==Verdict== On 25 March 2010, Judge Tom O'Donnell granted Limerick publicans an exemption from the state ban on opening on Good Friday. He recognised the potential for "controversy in several quarters".<ref name="Publicans toast court ruling on historic Good Friday opening"/>
Under Section 10 of the Intoxicating liquor Act 1962, applicants must possess a license to trade in the area, the area must not be the county borough of Dublin, an event of significance must be occurring in the area and there must be "a considerable amount" of people in the area: the judge agreed with all four points.<ref name="Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling"/> O'Donnell noted that one hotelier had described the match as having "an international flavour as journalists from the UK were booked into his hotel to report on the game [...] that over 2,000-room nights would be availed of and that certain hotels [...] had to turn away pre and post match functions. He even equated the match to be on a par with the famous [[Galway Plate]]".<ref name="Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling"/> O'Donnell responded to comparisons with a 1961 application for a dance licence in [[Kilkee]], 1971 judicial remarks on the definition of a "special event" and a 1984 [[High Court (Ireland)|High Court]] case which sought to clarify if a wedding was considered a "special event" in law by saying that none were in any way like this case and that there was no legal definition for the term "special event".<ref name="Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling"/><ref name="Publicans toast court ruling on historic Good Friday opening"/> O'Donnell described the application as "a last resort", observed that Thomond Park's stadium license would permit alcohol to be served on the day, that it would be "somewhat absurd" if the pubs lost out on business and also took into account that there were "health and safety reasons" for opening the pubs to serve the thousands of fans leaving the stadium when the match had ended.<ref name="Limerick pubs to open on Good Friday">{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0325/limerick.html|title=Limerick pubs to open on Good Friday|date=25 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref><ref name="Limerick pubs to open for game on Good Friday"/>
Publicans in Limerick were granted legal permission to trade between 18:00 and 23:30 on Good Friday 2010 (the application had sought hours of 18:00 until midnight).<ref name="Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling"/><ref name="Publicans toast court ruling on historic Good Friday opening"/> An area map delivered by the applicants had proposed the city of Limerick, Raheen Dooradoyle, Annacotty, Corbally, and Castletroy as the areas in which businesses would freely operate; the judge agreed with this and signed the map.<ref name="Cheers from publicans to landmark ruling"/>
{{cquote|Having considered all the submissions, I am satisfied that the match has all the vestiges and attributes of a special event. I accept that this decision may cause controversy in several quarters and, having considered the arguments, I wish to point out that the District Court is a court of record and not a court of precedent.—<small>Judge Tom O'Donnell upon delivering his verdict at Limerick District Court.</small><ref name="Limerick pubs to open for game on Good Friday">{{cite web|author=Áine de Paor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0326/1224267098143.html|title=Limerick pubs to open for game on Good Friday|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}}</ref>}}
===Reaction to verdict=== Solicitor for the applicants Gearoid McGann of Sweeney McGann Solicitors<ref>http://sweeneymcgann.com/index.html{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> called it "a groundbreaking decision".<ref name="Good Friday beer for fans while the Church fears for their spirits"/><ref name="Publicans toast court ruling on historic Good Friday opening">{{cite web|author=Barry Duggan|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/courts/publicans-toast-court-ruling-on-historic-good-friday-opening-2112567.html|title=Publicans toast court ruling on historic Good Friday opening|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> Limerick traders celebrated by selling t-shirts bearing slogans such as "Officially bigger than the Catholic Church: Munster Rugby", "Mass will now take place at Thomond Park" and "We have no bishop, no minister and no hurling team, but we can drink on Good Friday", referring to the scandal-hit [[Donal Murray (bishop)|Donal Murray]] ([[sexual abuse scandal in Limerick diocese]]), [[Willie O'Dea]] ([[Willie O'Dea affidavit incident|"brothelgate"]]) and an internal dispute involving the county's [[hurling]] team.<ref name="Irish wage rugby vs church war on T-shirts">{{cite web|author=Andras Gergely|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE62P1PN20100326|title=Irish wage rugby vs church war on T-shirts|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> Mayor Kiely asked that the law be updated to allow alcohol on all religious occasions: {{cquote|I don't see why Ireland discriminates against its own people. If people want to go to the pub and have a drink of<!--is this really the word he used?--> watch a sports match, they should be allowed to do that. Even the Vatican city doesn't have this ridiculous law. The law was last amended in 1928, and it is about time it is reviewed, because we are living in the dark ages.<ref name="Rugby Scores Irish Pubs A Very Good Friday">{{cite web|author=Laura Holmes |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Business/Pubs-In-Limerick-Win-Court-Battle-To-Open-On-Good-Friday-Due-Munster-v-Leinster-Rugby-Fixture/Article/201003415583866?lpos=Business_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_9&lid=ARTICLE_15583866_Pubs_In_Limerick_Win_Court_Battle_To_Open_On_Good_Friday_Due_Munster_v_Leinster_Rugby_Fixture |title=Rugby Scores Irish Pubs A Very Good Friday |date=26 March 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2010 |publisher=[[Sky News]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401142415/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Business/Pubs-In-Limerick-Win-Court-Battle-To-Open-On-Good-Friday-Due-Munster-v-Leinster-Rugby-Fixture/Article/201003415583866?lpos=Business_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_9&lid=ARTICLE_15583866_Pubs_In_Limerick_Win_Court_Battle_To_Open_On_Good_Friday_Due_Munster_v_Leinster_Rugby_Fixture |archivedate=1 April 2010 |df= }}</ref>}}
Mayor Kiely told the religious and anti-drinkers to "get real" and invited people from across Ireland to come to the city to drink on the day.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Dwane|url=http://www.limerickleader.ie/news/Mayor-invites-the-rest-of.6183707.jp|title=Mayor invites the rest of Ireland to Limerick for Good Friday and says objectors should 'get real'|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[Limerick Leader]]''}}</ref> Former [[President of the Gaelic Athletic Association|President]] of the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] [[Mick Loftus]] expressed his disappointment "in the light of the huge alcohol problem which this country is battling".<ref>{{cite web|author=Barry Roche, Patsy McGarry and Tom Shiel|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0326/1224267098131.html|title=Exemption reflects 'changing society'|date=26 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}}</ref>
Roman Catholic priests in Limerick made known their disappointment that this was to be "another long boozy weekend" in the city.<ref name="Irish pubs to open on Good Friday as locals worship rugby"/> Father Adrian Egan lamented: "Good Friday was a special day and a different day in our culture and our history – a day to slow down and reflect".<ref name="Irish wage rugby vs church war on T-shirts"/> Prayer vigils and [[Stations of the Cross]] rituals were planned to be performed outside the stadium by the religious.<ref>{{cite web|author=Áine de Paor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0316/1224266352431.html|title=Limerick publicans in court bid for Good Friday opening|date=16 March 2010|accessdate=27 March 2010|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}}</ref>

page.title: Gymnastics at the Pan American Games – Women's individual all-around

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=April 2012}} Women's events at the Gymnastics at the Pan American Games were first held at the 1959 Pan American Games. Three medals are awarded: [[gold medal|gold for first place]], [[silver medal|silver for second place]], and [[bronze medal|bronze for third place]]. [[Tie (draw)|Tie breakers]] have not been used in every year. In the event of a tie between two gymnasts, both names are listed, and the following position (second for a tie for first, third for a tie for second) is left empty because a medal was not awarded for that position. If three gymnastics tied for a position, the following two positions are left empty. ==Medalists== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = H. Dimurthala Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = [[Banda Aceh]], [[Aceh]] | address = Jl. H. Dimurthala, Lampineung, [[Banda Aceh]], [[Indonesia]] | coordinates = {{coord|5.565437|95.341260|region:ID_type:landmark|display=it}} | opened = 28 July 1957{{cite web|url=https://kumparan.com/@kumparanbola/nelangsa-h-dimurthala-potret-pilu-sepak-bola-banda-aceh.amp |title= Nelangsa H. Dimurthala, Potret Pilu Sepak Bola Banda Aceh |website= kumparan.com |language= indonesian |accessdate= 3 June 2018}} | renovated = 2018{{cite web|url=https://www.jawapos.com/sepak-bola/sepak-bola-indonesia/26/03/2018/stadion-h-dimurthala-terus-bersolek-sambut-liga-2-2018 |title= Stadion H. Dimurthala Terus Bersolek Sambut Liga 2 2018 |website= www.jawapos.com |language= indonesian |accessdate= 3 June 2018}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Banda Aceh]] Municipality | operator = | surface = [[Lawn|Grass pitch]] | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Lampineung Stadium | tenants = [[Persiraja Banda Aceh]]
[[Kuala Nanggroe F.C.]] | seating_capacity = 20,000 | dimensions = 100 m x 64 m | country = [[Indonesia]] | pushpin_map = Indonesia_Aceh#Indonesia | pushpin_map_caption = Location in [[Aceh]]##Location in [[Indonesia]] }} '''H. Dimurthala Stadium''' or previously known as '''Lampineung Stadium''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Banda Aceh]], [[Aceh]], [[Indonesia]]. The stadium holds 20,000 people. It is a homebase for [[Persiraja Banda Aceh]]. ==Facilities== Since the stadium is mainly used for football match, it does not have athletic track. It has dressing rooms, a secretariat room, and a press conference room. The single seats are only available for VIP at the east tribune. The east and west tribunes are roofed, whilst the north and south tribunes are not covered with roof (open tribune). ==Usage== It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. Besides that, it was also used for government employment test{{cite web|url=https://jpp.go.id/nasional/pemerintahan/310598-dipusatkan-di-stadion-38-000-orang-jalani-seleksi-cpns-kemenkumham-aceh |title= Dipusatkan di Stadion, 38.000 Orang Jalani Seleksi CPNS Kemenkumham Aceh|website= jpp.go.id |language= indonesian |accessdate= 3 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://beritakini.co/news/ribuan-orang-banjiri-stadion-lampineung-banda-aceh/index.html |title= Ribuan orang Banjiri Stadion Lampineung Banda Aceh|website= beritakini.co |language= indonesian |accessdate= 3 June 2018}} and as a venue for music concerts, such as: [[Noah (band)|Peterpan]]{{cite web|url=https://kapanlagi.com/amp/musik/berita/peterpan-tampil-memukau-di-nad-amygtg7.html |title= Peterpan tampil memukau di NAD|website= kapanlagi.com |language= indonesian |accessdate= 3 June 2018}} and [[Maher Zain]]{{cite web|url=https://seleb.tempo.co/amp/434891/maher-zain-konser-di-banda-aceh |title= Maher Zain Konser di Banda Aceh |website= tempo.co |language= indonesian |accessdate= 3 June 2018}}. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Banda Aceh]] [[Category:Sports venues in Indonesia]] [[Category:Football venues in Indonesia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1957]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Indonesia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Banda Aceh]]

revision.comment: Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/Noage187|Noage187]] ([[User talk:Noage187|talk]]): Needs to be properly sourced. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{About||the indoor bicycle sport with a format similar to ballet or gymnastics|Artistic cycling|the indoor bicycle sport with a format similar to football|Cycle ball|bicycle racing on banked indoor circuits|Track cycling|and|Velodrome}} {{multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=February 2014}} {{tone|date=September 2013}} }} '''Indoor cycling''', often also called '''spinning''', as an organized activity, is a form of exercise with classes focusing on endurance, strength, intervals, high intensity (race days) and recovery, and involves using a special stationary [[exercise bicycle]] with a weighted flywheel in a classroom setting.
== Class content and goals == [[File:Home cycling trainer 1897.jpg|thumbnail|"All the delight of outdoor cycling enjoyed at home" - article from 1897 describing indoor spin.]] Classes generally use specialized [[exercise bicycle|stationary bicycle]]s. Features include a mechanical device to modify the difficulty of pedalling, specially shaped handlebars, and multiple adjustment points to fit the bicycle to a range of riders. Many have a weighted [[flywheel]], which simulates the effects of inertia and momentum when riding a real bicycle. The pedals are equipped with toe clips as on sports bicycles to allow one foot to pull up when the other is pushing down. They may alternatively have [[bicycle pedal#Clipless pedals|clipless]] receptacles for use with cleated [[cycling shoe]]s. Padded shorts aid comfort and avoid the chafing caused by the sewn seams in underwear.
If the exercise is not done correctly or the rider's position is bad, injuries can occur; problems with the lower back and knees are most common. To avoid injury and aid comfort it is important to make sure the bio-mechanical position of the rider is correct. Group cycling bikes have a wide range of adjustment, and it is essential to obtain the correct setup prior to riding. The seat position must be right for the participant's height. The height of the seat should be in level with the hip when the participant is standing next to the cycle. Horizontally, the seat should be set in order for the front of the knee to be directly in vertical line with the [[Ball (anatomy)|ball of the foot]] when the pedal is pointing forward.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bodybike.dk/inspiration/good-advice|title=Good advice {{!}} BODY BIKE indoor cycles|website=www.bodybike.dk|language=en|access-date=2017-04-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://caloriesburnedhq.com/img/Spinner-Bike-Setup.pdf|title=Spin Shoes - Guide to Indoor Cycling Shoes|last=Chapman|first=Gareth|date=2017-02-12|work=Calories Burned HQ - Zumba Calories Burned, Calories Burned Walking|access-date=2017-04-15|language=en-US}}</ref> This results in a position where the knee is slightly bent at an angle between 25% and 35% when the leg is extended with the foot resting flat at the bottom of the pedal stroke. Handlebar height can be adjusted for comfort; less experienced riders may want to set them higher to ease lower back discomfort. A reasonable reference point is to set it in level with the seat.
[[Image:spinning-bike.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Indoor cycling - static bicycle health regimen. United Kingdom]] A typical class involves a single instructor at the front of the class who leads the participants through routines that are designed to simulate terrain and situations similar to riding a bike outdoors. Some of the movements and positions include hill climbs, sprints and [[interval training]]. A well-trained instructor uses [[music]], [[motivation]], visualization and enthusiastic coaching to lead students through a ride that best suits their fitness level and goals. Most instructors will lead what is called an interval ride, where students will sprint, run, climb, and jump all in the same ride, but there will not be definable pattern to the exercises. In the early 2000s, "terrain-based" classes that simulate outdoor conditions (e.g., wind resistance) were introduced. Terrain-based classes are designed to improve a rider's outdoor skill set and increase endurance while providing an intense cardio-based workout.
Participants set goals based on their [[heart rate]], which can be measured by hand or using a [[heart rate monitor]] and ride simulated variations in terrain by altering resistance and cadence. Some participants choose to maintain a moderate, [[aerobic exercise|aerobic]] intensity level, with a heart rate of between 50 and 85% of max while others drive their heart rates higher in intervals of [[anaerobic exercise|anaerobic]] activity to levels of between 85 and 92%.
One of the major advantages of indoor cycling is that each participant can exactly control his/her level of intensity to suit ability or fitness level but still remain as a group together. The classes can therefore be heterogeneous. As an alternative, participants can judge their level of exertion relative to a perceived exertion scale. The instructor should advise a recommended exertion scale from 1 (no exertion at all) to 10 (maximum exertion). Each rider is permitted to dictate how hard he/she chooses to work with the instructor providing active and dynamic encouragement together with technical and practical advice throughout the class.<ref>{{Cite web |title = Spinning Information on Healthline |accessdate = 2011-02-10 |url = http://www.healthline.com/natstandardcontent/alt-spinning |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110711155348/http://www.healthline.com/natstandardcontent/alt-spinning |archive-date = 2011-07-11 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
Besides burning (on average) between 300-500 kcal in 60 minutes,<ref>Darling, A. "Be Fit: The Science of Health: Part 2: Exercise: Feel the burn: Which workout is best for you? Andy Darling is your guide." Guardian, The. 2005, January 15: 28.</ref> indoor cycling also strengthens the muscles of the lower body. It tones the [[quadriceps]] and [[hamstring]]s, along with working the back and hips. It can be difficult to stay at the moderate level in a class that is geared towards more intensity. The difficulty of the workout is modulated in two ways:
#By varying the resistance on a [[flywheel]] attached to the pedals. The resistance is controlled by a knob, wheel or lever that the rider operates, causing the flywheel brake (a common bicycle brake, a friction wheel, a magnetic eddy-current brake, a viscoelastic fluid brake, or a strap running around the flywheel) to tighten. On most bikes the brake can be adjusted from completely loose, providing no resistance to pedaling beyond the inertia of the flywheel, to so tight that the rider can not move the pedals. Usually riders who can't pedal at the resistance called out by the instructor are encouraged to ride at a level at which they feel comfortable yet challenged. #By changing the cadence (the speed at which the pedals turn). Pedaling at a higher rate expends more energy than pedaling at a lower rate with the same resistance. Correct cadence is between the range of 80 to 110 RPM for seated flat, standing flat (running) and jumping and 60 to 80 RPM for seated climb, standing climb, running with resistance and jumps on a hill. Sprints are taken under hill resistance building cadence up to no more than 110 RPM. Seated sprints are most suitable as the rider maintains full control of posture at all times and will avoid falling due to exhaustion. A correct sprint should last from 10 to 25 seconds, leaving the rider exhausted in the 85 to 92% max heart rate range. [[File:Foundation-20F9-0353.jpg|thumb|Typical fixed wheel ergonomically adjustable variable resistance bike]] There are five core movements in the Spinning programme. *'''Seated flat''', with hands at the center part of the handlebars. This is hand position one. This position should be used only when seated, for flat road simulations and during the warm-up and cool down. Cadence between 80 and 110 RPM. *'''Standing flat''' (also known as '''running'''), with hands wide on the back 12-14" part of the handlebars that crosses the rider's body. This is hand position two. Proper form for standing while running requires the body to be more upright and the back of the legs touching or enveloping the point of the saddle, with the center of gravity directly over the crank. The pressure of body weight should never rest excessively on the handlebars. Cadence is between 80 and 110 RPM *'''Jumps''', (also known as '''lifts'''), a combination of seated and standing with riders hands at position two for durations of between two and eight seconds. Cadence between 80 and 110 RPM. *'''Seated climb''' with hands at position two, increased resistance and lower cadence of 60-80 RPM. *'''Standing climb''' with hands wide and forward so the thumb tips are touching the far end of the handlebars (hand position three). The rider is canted slightly forward so that maximum force can be exerted onto the pedals with heavy resistance and a cadence of 60-80 RPM.
These five movements each work a different part of the body and focus on different leg muscle groups. The rider should always maintain control of the flywheel by having resistance applied and remaining below a cadence of 110 RPM. Not all bikes have a freewheel, or 'smart release', and it is possible that the flywheel will 'run away' with the rider with the potential for causing injury. The rider should be able to maintain perfectly even pedal rotations at high resistance. This becomes difficult below 60 RPM cadence and failing to make 'perfect circles' increases the risk of knee and hip injury. A road cyclist will normally have a natural pedal cadence, of about 85 RPM and will control changes in terrain by changing gear to maintain this rate. The goal of the spinning programme is not to exceed this natural rate by more than 25 RPM higher (110 RPM) or lower (60 RPM) There are five further advanced movements based on those listed above. *'''Running with resistance''' *'''Jumps on a hill''' *'''Seated flat sprint''' *'''Seated hill sprint''' *'''Standing hill sprint'''
Most indoor cycling classes are coached with [[music]]. Riders may synchronize their pedalling to be in time with the rhythm of the music, thus providing an external stimulus to encourage a certain tempo. Often, the music chosen by the instructor is [[dance music]] or [[rock music]] set to a dance beat (i.e. 4/4 time), but not necessarily. This tends to help motivate participants to work harder than they might otherwise. The instructor also may choose specific songs for sprints, climbs, and jumps. While the music provides a tempo cue, the cadence does not need to be a multiple of the beat in order for the rider to feel in rhythm; the music therefore helps a rider maintain any constant cadence, not just a cadence that matches the beat. It may depend on the level of exertion whether or not someone changes position or the instructor can tell the class to change.
A variation known as "aqua cycling" or "hydrospinning" also exists. In this, the stationary bicycles are underwater in a pool.<ref name="Landreth">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/the-swimming-blog/2014/jan/21/hydrospinning-fitness-spin-class-cycling-underwater|title=Hydrospinning: the fitness craze that makes your spin class look easy|last=Landreth|first=Jenny|date=21 January 2014|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/health/2013/08/29/aqua-cycling-new-underwater-workout/|title=Aqua cycling: A new underwater workout|date=29 August 2013|work=[[Fox News Channel]]|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Spinning (2).jpg|Early examples of indoor cycling on [[Bicycle rollers|rollers]] File:Spinning (3).jpg|Stationary bicycle trainer File:Lawrence Beesley in the Gymnasticroom.jpeg|[[Lawrence Beesley]] in the Gymnastics Room of the ''[[Titanic]]'', 1912 </gallery>

revision.text:
{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:Judo newaza.jpg|thumb|These two judoka are wearing judogi]] '''''Judogi''''' (柔道着 or 柔道衣) is the formal [[Japanese language|Japanese]] name for the traditional uniform used for [[Judo]] practice and competition.
A judogi is somewhat similar to a [[karategi]] (空手着 or 空手衣, '''[[Karate]] uniform''') as it shares a common origin. [[Jigoro Kano]] derived the original Judogi from the [[Kimono]] and other Japanese garments around the turn of the 20th century, and, as such, the judogi was the first modern martial-arts-training uniform. Over the years, the sleeves and pants have been lengthened, the material and fit have changed, the traditional unbleached cotton is now a bleached white, and blue Judogi have become available; nevertheless, the uniform is still very close to that used 100 years ago. Other martial arts, notably [[Karate]], later adopted the style of training uniform that is used in Judo.<ref>{{cite book | last = Lowry | first = Dave | title = In the Dojo | publisher = Shambhala | year = 2006 | pages = 39–42 | location = Boston, Massachusetts | isbn = 978-0-8348-0572-9 }}</ref>
A judogi comprises three parts that are usually cut from different fabrics: a very heavy jacket (uwagi), lighter canvas pants (shitabaki), and a cotton belt (obi). Though similar to the shorter styles of kimono, an uwagi will invariably be made from heavy-weight [[cotton]] or cotton blend. All but the cheapest and lightest uwagi are cut from woven cotton, similar to, but much more tightly woven than, terrycloth. More expensive competition and hand-made judogi will often weigh several kilograms when finished. Due to the nature of judo practice, they commonly have heavier stitching and double-layered knee patches to provide durability. The obi's different colors denote the different ranks in judo.
[[File:Judo orange belt (Brusselsshrek).JPG|thumb|Close up view of a judogi]] In competition, judogi sizes and fit are strictly defined by the IJF rules of judo (see below). These rules define sleeve and pant length as well as the looseness of the fit; in competition, the referee can disqualify a competitor for wearing an ill-fitting judogi that may be used for advantage. In addition, various organizations and events oversee such matters as the attachment of commercial and team/national patches and competitors' names. All competitive judogi must be clean and free of holes, tears, or excessive wear.
In official national or international competition only white or blue judogi are allowed. Competitors must have available both colors because one contestant in each match is designated to wear a blue gi while the other wears a white gi. Most judo classes will permit students to wear either color, although white is the traditional color that is often preferred and white fits in better with the traditions of judo and Japanese culture. Less common colors, including red and black, can be found in less formal or specialized situations.
The left side of the gi must cross over the right one.
== Judogi weights == Judogi are sold in many thicknesses, which can be generally grouped together in the two classes: single-weave and [[Double weave|double-weave]]. Single-weave judogi are thinner and weigh less (upper jacket textile fabric weight usually 300–550 g/m<sup>2</sup>). The thinner judogi are less durable, although some judoka (judo practitioners) may prefer them for long practices as they are less likely to foster overheating. Double-weave judogi are thicker and weigh more (fabric weight usually 650–1050 g/m<sup>2</sup>). They are harder to grab than single-weave gis, which is considered an advantage in competition. Double-weave gis shrink less and those of high quality are often sold entirely pre-shrunk, this is important to know when comparing the fit of the gi. Double-weave gis generally cost considerably more than single-weave gis of comparable quality.
Pants by themselves should not be classified as single-weave or double-weave as the name only refers to the weaving style used for the upper section of the jacket. However, pants sold together with double-weave jackets will also tend to be heavier than normal due to stronger fabric or large reinforced sections.
Double-weave jackets designed for competition usually display a prominent seam that runs down the back of the jacket, joining two halves of fabric. Starting in the late nineties, some manufacturers made this overlapping part very wide, in effect doubling the fabric thickness for a large section of the back. This blocked the opponent from gripping there, which in 2005 caused the [[International Judo Federation]] to ban fighting in international competitions using a judogi with back seam area wider than 3 cm (a little more than one inch). Wider designs could still be permitted in local competitions depending on national rules. Single-weave jackets usually have no back seam, or a narrow one which only joins two fabric sections without interfering with grips.

{{Redirect|Square circle|the mathematical problem|Squaring the circle}}
'''Octorad''' is a term coined to describe a style of [[stadium]] architecture in the late 1960s. The term suggests eight radiuses, the design incorporating four [[Arc (geometry)|arc]]s of a large circle to comprise most of the structure, and four arcs of a smaller circle to round out the corners. It was a variant on the archetypal [[multi-purpose stadiums]] of the time, many of which were either conventionally circular or oval, and were often criticized for poor sight line angles for many spectators at [[baseball]] and [[football]] games.
The most prominent examples of the octorad style were [[Qualcomm Stadium]] in [[San Diego]], which opened in 1967 and still exists; and [[Veterans Stadium]] in [[Philadelphia]], which opened in 1971 and has since been demolished.
Both stadiums accomplished the goal of providing better sight lines for spectators. However, the architecture of those two stadiums still put a large majority of the fans far away from the action.
Other terms sometimes used for this design were "[[Superellipse|super circle]]" and "square circle".
<gallery> File:Superellipse rounded diamond.svg File:Qualcomm Stadium-baseball.jpg File:Veterans stade.png </gallery>

{{Infobox golf tournament | name = Pacific Links Bear Mountain Championship | image = Pacific Links Bear Mountain Championship logo.png | location = [[Victoria, British Columbia]], [[Canada]] | establishment = 2012 | course = [[Bear Mountain (resort)|Bear Mountain Resort]] | par = | yardage = | tour = [[PGA Tour Champions]] | format = [[Stroke play]] - 54 holes
(no cut) | purse = [[United States dollar|$]]2.5 million | month_played = September | final_year = | aggregate = 197 [[Paul Goydos]] (2014) | to-par = −19 [[Paul Goydos]] (2014) | current_champion = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Jerry Kelly]] | final_champion = }} {{Location map many | Canada | relief = yes | width = 240 | caption = Location in [[Canada]] | lat1_deg = 48.2801 | lon1_deg = -123.3135 | label1 = Bear Mountain
Resort | lat2_deg = | lon2_deg = | label2 = }} The '''Pacific Links Bear Mountain Championship''' is a professional [[golf]] tournament on the [[PGA Tour Champions]]. It was first played in September 2012 at the Kapolei Golf Course in [[Kapolei, Hawaii]],{{cite web |url=http://www.pgatour.com/champions/news/2012/07/15/PacificLinksHawaii.html |title=New Pacific Links Hawaii C'ship coming in September |publisher=PGA Tour |date=July 15, 2012 |accessdate=September 22, 2013}} which is owned and operated by [[Pacific Links International]]. It moved to the 27 Club in [[Tianjin]], China for the 2015 season{{cite web |url=http://www.pgatour.com/champions/news/2014/12/17/schedule-announcement.html |title=Champions Tour announces 2015 schedule |publisher=PGA Tour |date=December 17, 2014 |accessdate=December 18, 2014}} but was eventually canceled. It moved to [[Victoria, British Columbia]], [[Canada]] for the 2016 season {{cite web |url=http://www.pgatour.com/champions/news/2016/05/06/pacific-links-championship-moves-to-british-columbia.html |title=Canada’s Bear Mountain Resort named as host of 2016 Pacific Links Championship |publisher=PGA Tour |date=May 6, 2016 |accessdate=September 19, 2016}} The purse for the 2016 tournament was [[United States dollar|$]]2.5 million, with a winner's share of $375,000. ==Winners== {| class="wikitable" !Year||Dates||Champion||Country||Winning score||Margin||Purse ($) |- !colspan=7|Pacific Links {{Infobox venue |name=Parade Stadium |coordinates= {{Coord|44|58|15|N|93|17|31|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |type=Stadium |genre=football, concerts |opened=1951 |demolished=1990 |owner=Minneapolis Park & Recreation Board |cost=$600,000 |capacity=16,560 |record_attendance=30,000
(Melissa Manchester concert, June 1979) }} Parade Stadium is a former football stadium in [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]]. It was Minneapolis's first public football stadium. The [[Minneapolis Park and Recreation Board]] built the 16,560-seat stadium at The Parade, a park just west of downtown, in 1951. It was meant for high school, amateur, and small-college games.{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=David|title=Parade Stadium, Minneapolis|url=http://www.mnopedia.org/place/parade-stadium-minneapolis|website=MNopedia|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=February 21, 2017}} The stadium was also used for summertime [[Minneapolis Aquatennial]] festivities for over forty years.{{cite news|title=Aquatennial Program Highlights|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/183355995/|work=Minneapolis Star|date=July 18, 1965|via=Newspapers.com}} ==History== [[Thomas Lowry]], who lived on a hill overlooking the grounds, and others donated most of the land for The Parade to the Minneapolis park board in 1904.{{cite web |title=Parade Park - History |url=https://www.minneapolisparks.org/parks__destinations/parks__lakes/parade_park/#group_3_18425 |publisher=Minneapolis Park & Recreation Board |accessdate=24 December 2017}} The board did not act on Lowry's suggestion for a golf course for the park but did express its intent to use the area for active recreation purposes. In the spring of 1908, the park board developed five baseball fields at The Parade, which were the city's first public recreation facilities. They were so popular that a permit system was created. Two more baseball fields were added in the summer. The ball fields had practices every weeknight and games every Saturday. Athletics were not allowed on Sundays. That fall football goal posts were installed. The first citywide track meet was held in 1910 and the park board built four tennis courts in 1911. [[Woodrow Wilson]] gave a campaign speech at The Parade in 1912. After the seven baseball and two football fields were re-graded and open for play in 1914, the park became the center of amateur sports in the city. In the 1920s, some football games at The Parade attracted standing crowds estimated at 5,000 spectators. The park board proposed building a stadium there in 1933, and applied for federal public-works funding, but were unsuccessful. It tried again, in 1944, when it added a stadium to its list of "post-war progress" projects. The board claimed the city needed a stadium with a seating capacity between the huge [[Memorial Stadium (University of Minnesota)|Memorial Stadium]] at the [[University of Minnesota]] and various small park and school athletic fields. In 1950, the city finally approved $600,000 in bonds over two years to build only the stadium. To make room for it, the park board moved The Parade tennis center to Nicollet Park, since renamed Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Park. The stadium hosted its first major event in July 1951, when the [[Lone Ranger]] and Silver appeared at an Aquatennial children's event. That September, an exhibition football game between the [[Green Bay Packers]] and [[San Francisco 49ers]] drew 20,000 fans. At first, the stadium was a financial success, partly because of revenue from hosting an annual [[National Football League]] (NFL) exhibition game. But Parade Stadium was never intended to host professional games. When [[Metropolitan Stadium]] was built in [[Bloomington, Minnesota|Bloomington]] in 1956 to attract professional baseball and football to Minnesota, the yearly NFL exhibition game was played there. Parade Stadium continued hosting about 50 football games a year. The most popular were Friday-night and Saturday-night Minneapolis high school games. It hosted the annual Minnesota high school all-star football game for many years.{{cite web|title=Minnesota Football Showcase|url=http://www.allstarfootball.org/HISTORY/MNallstarlocations.pdf|website=www.allstarfootball.org|publisher=Minnesota Football Coaches Association|accessdate=28 December 2017|page=10}} Includes aerial photo. [[Augsburg University]]'s football team used Parade Stadium as its home field from 1951 to 1983. It also was the starting point of the two Aquatennial parades each summer. The park board booked other events, from midget-car races to circuses. But area residents objected to the noise and traffic. The costs of maintaining the stadium soon exceeded revenue. By the mid-1960s, the only moneymaker at The Parade was the parking lot. After the [[Guthrie Theater]] opened across the street in May 1963, most of its patrons parked in the stadium lot. In the mid-1960s, Parade Stadium generated income by booking top musical acts for outdoor rock concerts. [[Buffalo Springfield]], [[Jefferson Airplane]], [[Fleetwood Mac]], and [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]], among others, played there. Singer [[Melissa Manchester]] drew the stadium's largest crowd of 30,000 in June 1979. The last big-name act to play at Parade Stadium was [[Simon and Garfunkel]] in July 1983. Eventually, music promoters became unwilling to meet the growing limitations placed on concerts by the park board to address complaints from people who lived near the stadium. By 1986, only five events were booked there, two of which were Aquatennial parades. The structure was 35 years old, and the park board estimated that it needed $250,000 in renovations. In 1988, the park board collaborated with the [[Walker Art Center]] to create the [[Minneapolis Sculpture Garden]] on park land next to the stadium. The Sculpture Garden's popularity led to its expansion in 1990. A heavily used softball field had to be moved to accommodate that expansion. The logical place to put it was where the little-used stadium stood. As a result, Parade Stadium was demolished in 1990, the softball field was moved, and the Sculpture Garden expanded. The Walker paid the million-dollar price tag for demolition of the stadium and relocation of the softball field. ===NFL preseason games at Parade Stadium=== *September 12, 1951 [[San Francisco 49ers]] 20-0 [[Green Bay Packers]] *September 17, 1952 [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] 7-6 Green Bay Packers *August 22, 1953 Green Bay Packers 31-7 [[New York Giants]] *August 14, 1954 [[Chicago Cardinals]] 27-10 Green Bay Packers *September 6, 1955 New York Giants 17-14 [[Baltimore Colts]] *August 25 1962 [[History of the St. Louis Cardinals (NFL)|St Louis Cardinals]] 24-21 [[Minnesota Vikings]] ==Current uses== Since the football stadium was demolished, the baseball field on the site has been called Parade Stadium. It is the home field for [[Augsburg University]] baseball.{{cite web |title=Athletic Facilities -- Parade Stadium |url=http://athletics.augsburg.edu/sports/2009/3/16/parade-1.aspx |publisher=Augsburg College |accessdate=24 December 2017}} In 2006, the [[Minneapolis Park and Recreation Board]] added a synthetic turf football and soccer field near the site of the old football stadium. The entire athletic complex is called Parade Park and includes the three-sheet Parade Ice Garden.{{cite web|title=Parade Ice Garden|url=https://www.minneapolisparks.org/parks__destinations/parks__lakes/parade_ice_garden/|publisher=Minneapolis Park & Recreation Board|accessdate=24 December 2017|language=en}} ==References== {{reflist}} ===Sources=== {{MNopedia |title=Parade Stadium, Minneapolis |url=http://www.mnopedia.org/place/parade-stadium-minneapolis |first=David C. |last=Smith |no-icon=1}} * Charles E. Doell papers. Manuscript Collection, Hennepin History Museum, Minneapolis. * Doell, Charles E. "The New Stadium at the Parade at Minneapolis." Minnesota Engineer, September 1951. * "Fine Park Is Assured." Minneapolis Tribune, November 15, 1903. * Minneapolis Board of Park Commissioners. Annual Reports, 1908, 1911, 1932, 1933, 1944, 1950, and 1951. * "Parade Stadium's Decline May Spell Its Demise." Minneapolis Star and Tribune, August 20, 1986. * "Sculpture Garden Will Grow; Parade Stadium to Come Down." Minneapolis Star Tribune, February 7, 1990. * {{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=David C.|title=City of Parks: The Story of Minneapolis Parks|date=2008|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|url=http://www.upress.umn.edu/book-division/books/city-of-parks}} * "The Parade Controversy." Minneapolis Tribune, May 23, 1950. * Walker Art Center. Minneapolis Sculpture Garden: A Collaboration between the Walker Art Center and the Minneapolis Park and Recreation Board. Minneapolis: Walker Art Center, 1998. * Wright, C. Ben. "Minneapolis Parks and Recreation: A History of the Park and Recreation Board, 1944–1978." Typescript, 1982. ==External links== *{{cite web |url=http://www.mnopedia.org/place/parade-stadium-minneapolis |title=Parade Stadium, Minneapolis |work=MNopedia |publisher=Minnesota Historical Society |accessdate=December 23, 2017 |first=David |last=Smith |date=February 21, 2017}} [[Category:Sports venues in Minneapolis]] [[Category:1951 establishments in Minnesota]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in Minnesota]] [[Category:1990 disestablishments in Minnesota]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1951]] [[Category:Defunct American football venues]] [[Category:Wikipedia articles incorporating text from MNopedia]] [[Category:Parks in Minneapolis]]

August 2016] ''Retrieved 11.08.2016 Macedonian'' | dimensions = }} '''Public swimming pool Kumanovo''' is a [[sport venue]] in [[Kumanovo]], Republic of Macedonia, that contains an Olympic-size indoor swimming pool and an outdoor swimming pool open for the general public.[http://www.libertas.mk/galerija-gradskite-bazeni-vo-kumanovo-svecheno-pushteni-vo-upotreba/ ГАЛЕРИЈА: Градските базени во Куманово свечено пуштени во употреба 2.08.16] ''Retrieved 11.08.2016 Macedonian'' The venue was financed by the [[Kumanovo Municipality]] and it was completed and opened for public on August 2nd 2016. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=diYurlgJUDs Video Plan of Indoor Pool in Kumanovo, Macedonia] *[http://kumanovo.gov.mk/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/pravilnik-za-koristenje.pdf Regulation of using the Swimming Pool] ''Macedonian'' * [http://www.build.mk/?p=51470 Photo Gallery] ''Macedonian'' {{Kumanovo |state=collapsed}} {{coord missing|Macedonia}} [[Category:Kumanovo]] [[Category:Kumanovo Municipality]] {{RMacedonia-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Renegades FC | image = Lyford Cay FC Osprey.png | image_size = 200px | fullname = Renegades Football Club | nickname = Ospreys | founded = 1989 | ground = [[Roscow A. L. Davies Soccer Field]]
[[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]], [[Bahamas]] | capacity = 1,700 | chairman = Stefano Donati | manager = Gavin Watchorn | league = [[BFA Senior League]] | season = 2013–14 | position = 1st | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = _whitehoophigh | pattern_ra1 = | pattern_sh1 = | pattern_so1 = | leftarm1 = FFDB00 | body1 = FFDB00 | rightarm1 = FFDB00 | shorts1 = FFFFFF | socks1 = FFDB00 }} '''Renegades Football Club''' (formerly known as '''Lyford Cay Football Club'''http://www.bahamasfa.com/clubs/club/6/lyford_cay_fc.html) is a [[Bahamas|Bahamian]] [[Association football|football]] club based in [[Lyford Cay]] while playing its home game in the capital [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]]. The team plays in the [[BFA Senior League]]. The team is also known by its nickname of the '''Ospreys''' (the '''Dragons''' until 2015), to distinguish it from a second Lyford Cay FC that has simultaneously played in the BFA Senior League (as recently as 2013–14) nicknamed the "[[Lyford Cay FC (Warriors)|Warriors]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bahama2014.html|title=Bahamas 2013/14|author=RSSSF.com|accessdate=March 6, 2015}} The Warriors serve as the reserve team for the Ospreys. The club was founded in 1989 and has grown significantly over the past twenty-five years moving from a school-based football program to an established football club and registered member of the [[Bahamas Football Association]] (BFA). Lyford Cay FC won its first National Championship in 2013–14. Building on this title, the team became the first Bahamian team to compete in the [[CFU Club Championship]] in [[2015 CFU Club Championship|2015]]. In September 2017 Lyford Cay FC changed it name with the permission of the [[Bahamas Football Association]] to Renegades FC ==Achievements== *'''[[BFA Senior League]]:'''{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bahamachamp.html|title=Bahamas – List of Champions|author=RSSSF.com|accessdate=March 6, 2015}} ::Champion (1): 2014 ::Runner-up (3): 2010, 2011, 2013 *'''Bahamas FA Cup:'''{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bahamacuphist.html|title=Bahamas – List of Cup Winners|author=RSSSF.com|accessdate=March 6, 2015}} ::Runner-up (1): 2010 ==Performance in International Competitions== *'''[[2015 CFU Club Championship]]''' ''Played in [[Haiti]]'' ::First Round v. {{flagicon|HAI}} [[Don Bosco FC|Don Bosco]] 0–10 ::First Round v. {{flagicon|VIR}} [[Helenites]] 1–0 ::First Round v. {{flagicon|GLP|local}} [[USR Sainte-Rose]] 2–2 ==Colors and Badges== [[File:Lyford Cay FC.png|left|thumb|160px|Logo used until 2015, when the team's nicknamed changed from "Dragons" to "Osprey".]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} {{-}} {{BFA Senior League}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Renegades Football Club}} [[Category:Football clubs in the Bahamas]] {{Bahamas-footyclub-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Young Rhythm | image = | fullname = Sport Vereniging The Young Rhythm | nickname = | founded = | dissolved = | ground = [[George Deul Stadion]]
[[Cottica]], [[Suriname]] | capacity = 1,500 | owntitle = Owner | owner = | chrtitle = President | chairman = | mgrtitle = Manager | manager = | league = [[SVB Eerste Klasse|Eerste Klasse]] | season = [[2014–15 Surinamese Eerste Klasse|2014–15]] | position = | website = | current = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | pattern_sh1 = | leftarm1 = | body1 = | rightarm1 = | shorts1 = | socks1 = | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_sh2 = | leftarm2 = | body2 = | rightarm2 = | shorts2 = | socks2 = }} '''Sport Vereniging The Young Rhythm''' is a Surinamese football club based in [[Cottica]]. The club presently competes in the [[SVB Eerste Klasse|Eerste Klasse]], the 2nd tier of [[Football in Suriname|Surinamese football]].{{cite web|title=Young Rhythm|url=http://nl.scoresway.com/?sport=soccer&page=team&id=10474|publisher=Scoresway.com|accessdate=30 January 2016}} In the 2003–04 [[SVB Hoofdklasse]] season, [[Owen van Cooten]] finished as the league [[List of SVB Hoofdklasse top scorers|top goal scorer]] with 26 goals scored while playing for Young Rhythm.{{cite web|title=Surinam – List of Topscorers|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/suritops.html|publisher=RSSSF.com|accessdate=30 January 2016}} The team play their local 'Cottica derby' against crosstown rivals Wanhattie at the George Deul Stadion.{{cite web|title=WSO wil sterke kandidaten leveren|url=http://dagbladdewest.com/2015/02/05/wso-wil-sterke-kandidaten-leveren/|publisher=Dagblad De West|accessdate=30 January 2016}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Hoofdklasse (suriname)}} {{SVB Eerste Klasse}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Young Rhythm}} [[Category:Football clubs in Suriname]] {{Suriname-footyclub-stub}}
